image.altText: A headshot photo of a man aged in his mid forties with a 'mullet' hairstyle.

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian man convicted of attempting to kill his ex-partner and murdering her new boyfriend entered their home in the early hours of the morning and stabbed them, while his own son tried to stop him.

title.children: 'He told me … he'd put me down': Man convicted over stabbing rampage involving former partner and new boyfriend

image.altText: A line drawing of a woman cradling a baby with a hospital bed behind.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian mothers have been speaking out on their birth experiences as part of a parliamentary inquiry investigating maternity services in the state.

title.children: Claire planned to have a large family, but a birth injury left her infertile. Hers is one of the stories before an inquiry

image.altText: A middle aged woman with a light brown bob and glasses speaks in front of small microphones mounted on a desk.

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has kept interest rates on hold at a 12-year high of 4.35 per cent after its June meeting, while the Australian share market has ended 1 per cent higher at the end of trade.

title.children: RBA considered rate hike at June meeting but decided on 'staying the course' to curb inflation — as it happened

image.altText: Sliding glass doors into a building with the words Reserve Bank of Australia written above.

props.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has kept rates on hold at its June meeting, leaving the cash rate at 4.35 per cent, as RBA governor says she's not expecting a recession.

title.children: RBA keeps interest rate at 4.35 per cent, says rate rise could be on cards as governor says she's not expecting a recession in Australia

image.altText: A young white woman reaches out and touches the shoulder of a young Chinese man amid a crowd of reporters.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has weighed in in defence of Australian journalist Cheng Lei after she was obstructed by Chinese embassy officials.

title.children: 'Clumsy' Cheng Lei incident prompts complaint from Australian government to Chinese embassy

image.altText: Graphic image showing three illustrations of people beside a 'winners and losers' sign, with a map of NSW in the background.

props.synopsis: Housing for essential workers and billions in funding for new and upgraded schools are just some of the big-ticket items in NSW Treasurer Daniel Mookhey's second budget.

title.children: Who are the winners and losers in this year's NSW budget?

image.altText: Co-living by Gallery Group house from their web page.

props.synopsis: With growing demand for share houses, some say co-living could be the alternative — but others say it's just a marketing ploy.

title.children: 'A race to the bottom': People are turning to co-living to beat the rental market, but some say it's a slippery slope

image.altText: A composite image of Robert Irwin on the left sitting on a chair and smiling and Pauline Hanson in a red blouse grimacing

props.synopsis: Pauline Hanson's One Nation party ignored Robert Irwin's demand the video be removed by 5pm on Monday, with the son of Steve Irwin portrayed alongside Bluey in unapproved political messaging ahead of October's state election.

title.children: Robert Irwin stays silent on his Pauline Hanson defamation threat as deadline passes

image.altText: A blurry photo of a plane with a flame coming from it.

props.synopsis: A passenger on a Melbourne-bound flight which had to make an emergency landing in New Zealand after an engine caught fire has praised the pilots for managing a safe descent and ensuring no-one was injured.

title.children: Passenger praises pilots after Virgin flight to Melbourne makes emergency landing due to engine fire

image.altText: Three men wearing black sitting side by side on a table. A blue and white Israeli flag is in the background.

props.synopsis: The Israeli prime minister had disbanded the war cabinet overseeing military decisions in Gaza after the resignation of one of its three members. The move will likely consolidate Benjamin Netanyahu's influence over the conflict.

title.children: Israel's PM has dissolved his war cabinet. What does that mean?

image.altText: Soldiers march towards other troops in a line.

props.synopsis: South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff says it doesn't believe the North Koreans intruded the border intentionally and that the North did not return fire.

title.children: South Korea fires shots after North Korean troops cross border

image.altText: A sick-looking woman with long brown hair wipes her nose with a tissue while sitting in front of a laptop, talking on a phone.

props.synopsis: You can now use an online statutory declaration as evidence for personal leave from work, without a JP signature.

title.children: The free document you can download online and use for sick leave

image.altText: Caged hen at Werribee in Victoria

props.synopsis: Poultry farmers continue to fight Australia's largest outbreak of avian influenza as the disease is detected at a seventh Victorian farm.

title.children: More than one million birds to be killed in Victoria to stop the spread of deadly disease

image.altText: A woman with frustrated expression seen looking into laptop screen with blurred kitchen behind her.

props.synopsis: Fake job listings are increasingly used by companies to give the illusion they're thriving and to placate overworked staff. If you're applying for work, there are plenty of clues to look out for to avoid wasting your time.

title.children: Fake job ads waste applicants' time and harm their wellbeing. So why are companies posting them?

image.altText: Small people figurines stand in front of an Adobe logo design

props.synopsis: The US government is suing Adobe, accusing the design software giant of "trapping" customers into year-long subscriptions through concealing hefty termination fees and making it difficult for members to cancel.

title.children: Software giant Adobe accused of 'trapping' customers into subscriptions, making it difficult to cancel

image.altText: Senator Fatima Payman asking a question at Environment estimates committee

props.synopsis: Fatima Payman has distanced herself further from the Albanese government’s formal policy on Gaza, insisting recognition of Palestinian statehood was necessary in the face of "genocidal acts" by Israel.

title.children: Labor senator demands recognition of Palestinian statehood

image.altText: A four-wheel-drive on Teewah Beach

props.synopsis: Indigenous elders say a landmark native title claim in heavily urbanised and tourist destinations of south-east Queensland will not change the way people enjoy or live in the area.

title.children: 'Life will still go on' after successful Kabi Kabi native claim in south-east Queensland

image.altText: A fish hanging from a hook in it's mouth. River and green grassy banks in background.

props.synopsis: Commercial gillnet fishing for barramundi will be phased out across the Northern Territory from August after both of the territory's major parties announced their support for an end to the practice.

title.children: Commercial gillnet fishing for barramundi to be phased out across the NT

image.altText: A man with grey hair dressed in camoflauge gear prepares a drone for flight next to a man staring at a laptop screen.

props.synopsis: Commander Anton is part of an elite squad of Ukrainian soldiers who call themselves the "Peaky Blinders" after the violent British television drama. Here's how they managed to stop Russia's advance after its surprise offensive in May.

title.children: As Ukrainians hold off an offensive from the enemy, the ABC was taken to a secret position near the Russian border

image.altText: White bags of minerals line a factory floor

props.synopsis: Pandas might have dominated the headlines when the Chinese Premier visited South Australia, but the only other state Li Qiang is visiting has bigger ambitions — and its all about mining.

title.children: Lobster is served as Premier Li heads west, but what's in these bags has WA most excited

image.altText: A woman turns a switch on an electric heater.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian power prices will remain almost unchanged for the next 12 months and, when combined with state and federal government rebates, consumers could see an overall reduction.

title.children: Tasmania's power prices would have actually dropped had network costs not 'spoiled the party', regulator says

image.altText: Woman with hair tied back looks directly into the camera, not smiling.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian Education Department and one of its former teachers have been ordered to pay victim-survivor of child sexual abuse, Katrina Munting, combined damages of more than $2 million for abuse she suffered in the late 1990s.

title.children: 'Gaining our power back': State and teacher ordered to pay more than $2m to victim-survivor of child sexual abuse

image.altText: A softly lit street light.

props.synopsis: Birmingham was once a powerhouse industrial metropolis, but now the UK's second city is a shell of its former self as rubbish lines the streets, the lights stay off and children grow up below the poverty line.

title.children: The UK's second-biggest city is so broke it can no longer keep the lights on

image.altText: White frost covers the grass in Canberra as cows graze

props.synopsis: Eastern Australia will continue to shiver through unusually cold temperatures for the rest of the week, with some capitals facing their coldest morning of the year so far, days out from the winter solstice.

title.children: Large parts of Australia stuck in cold snap as shortest day of year nears

image.altText: Connor Garden-Bachop playing for the Highlanders in 2024.

props.synopsis: The New Zealand rugby union community comes together to pay respect to Māori All Blacks representative Connor Garden-Bachop, who died on Monday aged 25.

title.children: New Zealand rugby in mourning after Māori All Black dies following 'medical event'

image.altText: Gymnast Emily Whitehead of Australia jumps in the air, with arms and legs stretched out, in competition on the mat

props.synopsis: Australia names its largest-ever gymnastics squad for the Paris Games, featuring the youngest Australian rhythmic gymnast in 40 years and the youngest male trampoline gymnast ever.

title.children: Youth and experience combine as Australia names largest gymnastics team for Paris 2024

image.altText: Dozens of people stand in a line on a steep hill with a large flat-top mountain in the distance

props.synopsis: Time is running out in South Africa to find solutions to its real-world problems — otherwise the country may well become another textbook case on what happens when inequality is allowed to fester.

title.children: South Africa's future depends on an 'unholy alliance' solving its real-world problems before time runs out

image.altText: A white woman with long blonde hair sitting in a wheelchair in a lounge room

props.synopsis: Ambulatory wheelchair users are relatively common but say they often face judgement and accusations they're faking their disabilities. This is what they want you to know.

title.children: It's not safe for Shae to walk everywhere, but she still gets accosted for using a wheelchair

image.altText: Ian McKellen in a leather jacket holding a glass.

props.synopsis: The 85-year-old was performing in a production of Player Kings when about two hours into the show he fell off the stage.

title.children: Ian McKellen rushed to hospital after falling off stage during play

image.altText: The crutch of the statue of David, with an eggplant emoji over his genitals. A tourist with binoculars looks on

props.synopsis: The world's most famous classicist helps unpack the mystery behind statue penis-size and shares her theory on why so many men are obsessed with the Roman Empire.

title.children: 'It's the $64,000 question': Why do ancient statues have such teeny-tiny penises?

image.altText: A close up on a fair-skinned woman's hands in fabric work gloves holding a snapped purple sweet potato above red dirt.

props.synopsis: A nutritionist says purple sweet potatoes have higher antioxidants than the more popular gold variety and are a cost-effective food for families.

title.children: Colourful varieties of kitchen staple win praise for packing healthy punch

image.altText: A dozen members of the women's NSW state of origin team smiling and hugging after a try was scored

props.synopsis: After coming close to wrapping up the series on home soil, before a Queensland fightback led to a 11-10 Maroons win, Sky Blues coach Kylie Hilder has shown faith in the same 17 women to secure the historic decider in Townsville.

title.children: Sky Blues name unchanged side for historic Women's Origin decider

image.altText: A snapshot from a police officer's body cam shows hands reaching for a small, pink piglet on a road.

props.synopsis: A pet piglet has surprised police in Northern California with its speed and strength during a frantic chase through town.

title.children: Pickles the pig leads Californian police on frantic chase

image.altText: Melbourne chiropractor Ian Rossborough cracks a baby's back

props.synopsis: The Chiropractic Board of Australia has reinstated an interim ban on the spinal manipulation of children under the age of two following a request from federal and state health ministers.

title.children: Ban on chiropractors manipulating the spines of babies reinstated following outcry from doctors

image.altText: Kartanya Maynard is wearing a linen off-site shirt, posing under an off-white sheet.

props.synopsis: Stolen is based on the real-life experiences of members of the Stolen Generations. Its message is as relevant now as when the play was first written nearly three decades ago.

title.children: 22,000 First Nations kids are in out-of-home care today. That's why this 90s play is still relevant
